verses.text: When Saul’s son heard that Abner had died in Hebron, his courage failed, and all Israel was alarmed.
verses.comment: Saul’s son refers to Ish-bosheth; 'courage failed' translates 'his hands became weak'.

verses.text: Saul’s son had two men who were captains of raiding bands. The name of the first was Baanah, and the name of the second was Rechab, sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, from the tribe of Benjamin. (Beeroth is counted among Benjamin,
verses.comment: The geographical note follows the original. 'Captains of raiding bands' is often rendered 'leaders of troops' or 'companies.'

verses.text: because the Beerothites fled to Gittaim and have lived there as foreigners to this day.)

Jonathan, Saul’s son, had a son who was lame in both feet. He was five years old when the news about Saul and Jonathan came from Jezreel, and his nurse picked him up and fled. But as she hurried away, he fell and became lame. His name was Mephibosheth.
verses.comment: Mephibosheth is introduced here; 'lame in both feet' updates 'lame on both feet.'

verses.text: Now the sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, Rechab and Baanah, went and came about noon to the house of Ish-bosheth, as he was lying on his bed at midday.
verses.comment: 'Went and came' preserves the Hebrew verb pair, and 'midday' is kept for accuracy.

verses.text: They entered the house as if they were fetching wheat, and stabbed him in the stomach. Then Rechab and Baanah, his brother, escaped.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts reorder verse 6 and 7; this follows main Masoretic order.

verses.text: When they had gone into the house, he was lying on his bed in his bedroom; they attacked and killed him, then took his head and fled by the way of the Arabah all night.
verses.comment: Sequence preserves original narrative; 'Arabah' is untranslated, meaning the Jordan Valley.

verses.text: They brought the head of Ish-bosheth to David at Hebron and said to the king, 'Here is the head of Ish-bosheth, son of Saul, your enemy, who sought your life. The LORD has avenged my lord the king this day against Saul and his offspring.'
verses.comment: Quotes preserved as direct speech; 'avenged' reflects Hebrew root for vengeance.

verses.text: But David answered Rechab and Baanah, his brother, sons of Rimmon the Beerothite, 'As the LORD lives, who has delivered me from all distress,
verses.comment: David asserts God’s providence instead of man's actions.

verses.text: 'when someone told me, “Saul is dead,” and thought he was bringing good news, I seized him and killed him in Ziklag—which was what he deserved for his news.'
verses.comment: David references the Amalekite report and execution (see 2 Sam 1).

verses.text: 'How much more, when wicked men have killed a righteous man in his own house on his bed! Shall I not now require his blood from your hand and destroy you from the earth?'
verses.comment: David underscores the gravity of murdering an innocent ('righteous') in his home.

verses.text: So David commanded the young men, and they killed them, cut off their hands and feet, and hung them beside the pool in Hebron. But they took the head of Ish-bosheth and buried it in Abner’s tomb at Hebron.
verses.comment: Public punishment emphasizes justice; burial respects Saul’s house.
